docs.lead_paragraph: The Lystedt Law in Washington State has served as a template for states that have enacted or are considering similar bills, but it can still leave young athletes in danger.

docs.lead_paragraph: An article on Saturday about benefits in the new health care law for small businesses misstated the effect of rising insurance costs on a bookstore in Utah. Health care costs have grown to account for a third of the store's payroll expenses, not its revenue. The article also misidentified the source of the comment that small-business employees had been particularly vulnerable to certain lapses in insurance coverage. The observation was made by several people who were interviewed; the comment was not by John Arensmeyer, chief executive of Small Business Majority.

docs.lead_paragraph: The health care reform legislation, the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, turns six months old today. And while the main features of the act won't go into effect until 2014, the government has begun laying the foundation for the law's major pillars. This report -- the first in a series -- grades progress in three main areas: ''Rollout'' (Are critical milestones being met?); ''Reactions'' (Are key health care and political players cooperating?); and ''Results'' (Is health care reform actually reining in insurance premiums and insuring more Americans?).
docs.abstract: Prof Jacob S Hacker and Carl DeTorres Op-Chart is first in series that will evaluate government's progress as it lays foundations for health care reform legislation to become law (M)

byline.original: By JACOB S. HACKER and CARL DeTORRES

docs.lead_paragraph: 1:39 p.m. | Updated FALLS CHURCH, Va. -- President Obama traveled to a suburban backyard here this morning to listen to stories of patients who have been helped by his health care bill as part of a White House effort to promote the legislation with just six weeks left before Election Day.

headline.main: Democrats Grope for Health Care's Political Payoff

docs.abstract: Democrats don't generally advertise their support for the health care overhaul, but as the law's first effects are felt, President Obama highlights them.
